Package com.pranab.playwithgraphs.weightedgraphs.directed

Class AdjacencyListDirectedWeightedGraph<V,​K,​W extends Weight>

java.lang.Object
com.pranab.playwithgraphs.weightedgraphs.directed.AdjacencyListDirectedWeightedGraph<V,​K,​W>
Type Parameters:
V - - Value object that is encapsulated with DirectedWeightedNode to create a vertex
K - - Uniquely identify the new Vertex created.
W - - An entity that implements Weight so as to simulate strength of relationship as integer values.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Graph<V,​K>, DirectedWeightedGraph<V,​K,​W>, WeightedGraph<V,​K,​W>
public class AdjacencyListDirectedWeightedGraph<V,​K,​W extends Weight>
extends java.lang.Object
implements DirectedWeightedGraph<V,​K,​W>
An adjacency list implementation of the weighed Directed graph. A directed weighed graph is graph, i.e., a set of objects (called vertices or nodes) that are connected together, where all the edges are directed from one vertex to another with varying edge lengths. Graphs realization can be achieved through matrix or adjacency list. HashMap is used as an internal storage unit allowing unique key to identify each Vertex. Vertex is an instance of DirectedWeightedNode which encapsulates the value provided.
Author:
Pranab Bharadwaj

    The procedure creates Node/Vertex identified by a Unique Key in the graph.

    Returns all the target keys of the edges whose source is from the node identified by the provided key
    Time Complexity : O(n) where n - is the number of edges from source node.
    java.util.List<java.util.List<K>> getStrongConnectedComponent()
    Identifies all the strongly connected components in a given graph.
    The algorithm implemented is Kosarajuâ€™s algorithm which is basically running DFS twice
    once on the given graph followed by running the same on reversed graph
    Time complexity : O(V+E) V- vertices E- edges
    java.util.List<K> getTopologicalOrdered()
    does a topologically sorting of given graph.
    A topological sort or topological ordering of a directed graph is a linear ordering of its vertices such that for every directed edge uv from vertex u to vertex v, u comes before v in the ordering
    Time complexity : O(V+E) V- vertices E- edges

    • searchLevel

      public java.util.List<V> searchLevel​(K startingKeyPoint, int searchLevel, boolean includeBeforeLevel)
      provides a level wise search from the source node provided.
      Level 1 - returns all the nodes directly linked with source node.
      Level 2 - returns all the nodes directly linked to the nodes returned in Level 1.
      The implementation basically does a Breadth First Search.
      Time complexity : O(V+E) V- vertices E- edges
      Specified by:
      searchLevel in interface DirectedWeightedGraph<V,​K,​W extends Weight>
      Parameters:
      startingKeyPoint - - the node which acts as the source node or the starting point of search
      searchLevel - - integer value emphasizing the level from the source node which needs to be searched.
      includeBeforeLevel - - boolean value when true includes the previous level nodes in the result
      Returns:
      a list of keys of the Vertices present in that level Or the list of keys till that level depending on includeBeforeLevel variable value

    • searchSortestPath

      public java.util.Queue<K> searchSortestPath​(K startingKeyPoint, K targetKeyPoint)
      finds the shortest path between two given Nodes/Vertex
      Dijkstra's algorithm implementation using min priority queue. Time Complexity : O(ElogV) V- vertices E- edges. However the implementation as of now isn't providing an tight upper bound as there is a call to minheap's getindex which runs with time complexity of O(n).
      Tuning in progress
      Specified by:
      searchSortestPath in interface DirectedWeightedGraph<V,​K,​W extends Weight>
      Parameters:
      startingKeyPoint - - the node which acts as the source node or the starting point
      targetKeyPoint - - the target node to which the path needs to be identified
      Returns:
      list of all the nodes that make up the path to the targeted node.
